awd_titl_txt: CAREER: D3: Addressing Emerging Data-Induced Challenges in Embedded and Real-Time Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Data-driven embedded systems are here. The ability to create algorithms that process massive amounts of real-time sensor-captured data is enabling designers in many industries to develop intelligent embedded systems that automate actions and decisions, e.g., self-driving vehicles. This emerging data-intensive embedded computing paradigm brings a new set of data-induced challenges around guaranteeing timing predictability and enabling latency constraints to be analytically validated at design time. The goal of this research is to overcome challenges due to real-time processing of massive data in embedded systems in order to guarantee timing predictability. 

D3, a comprehensive resource management ecosystem with the capability of predictably processing massive real-time data-intensive workloads, is implemented in the operating system. D3 brings in a novel set of fundamental system-level techniques, which enable smart data filtering and characterization, transparent and supervised streaming for execution concurrency optimization, and predictable memory management under heterogeneous architectures. The hard algorithmic challenges due to co-scheduling memory and highly heterogeneous computing resources such that analytical guarantees on timing predictability become quantifiable will be addressed. 

Developing a comprehensive heterogeneous resource management ecosystem for predictably processing massive real-time data-intensive workloads would be a significant result for many application domains, such as transportation and robotics. The next-generation automotive system is a good example that could greatly benefit from the proposed research. The outcome of this project will pave the way to certifiability of safety-critical autonomous vehicles based on heterogeneous platforms. An innovative undergraduate research project to develop an educational tool that uses real-time data-driven system design concepts as its foundation assists in realizing the educational objectives. 

All source code and evaluation data will be freely available for direct download from public web servers maintained by the University of Texas at Dallas (UTD) Computer Science Department under an open source Gnu Public License. Additional case-study test programs and scripts will be freely available under the open source BSD license and directly downloadable from public web servers maintained by the UTD Computer Science Department. All data products produced in this project will also be archived in the UTD computer science computing repository for permanent storage. The repository is available at www.utdallas.edu/~cong/CareerRepo.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

por.por_cntn:
This project project embarked on an ambitious journey six years ago, aiming to revolutionize the way embedded and real-time systems handle vast amounts of data and utilize resources that often exhibit stringent Size, Weight, and Power (SWaP) constraints. In a world increasingly reliant on technology, from autonomous vehicles to smart healthcare devices, the need for systems that can process information swiftly and accurately has never been more critical. Our goal was to ensure these systems could meet their potential, enhancing safety, efficiency, and reliability across various sectors.

At the heart of our project was the development of a novel resource management ecosystem named "D3". This system was designed to tackle the challenges of data-intensive computing, ensuring that embedded systems could process real-time data without compromise. Through our research, we introduced groundbreaking techniques for smart data filtering, efficient memory management, and execution concurrency optimization. These innovations have paved the way for embedded systems to not only handle the data deluge but do so in a manner that guarantees timing predictability - a critical requirement for the safety and reliability of systems such as autonomous vehicles.

Our work has yielded a comprehensive framework that significantly advances the state-of-the-art in embedded system design. By addressing the complex algorithmic challenges involved in co-scheduling memory and computing resources, we've provided quantifiable guarantees on system performance. This framework has been rigorously tested through extensive experiments, involving synthetic workloads, benchmarks, and real-world automotive applications, demonstrating its efficacy and potential for widespread adoption.

The implications of our research extend far beyond the realms of computer science and engineering. By enhancing the reliability and efficiency of data-driven systems, our work contributes to the advancement of numerous application domains, including transportation, healthcare, and agriculture. For instance, the improvements in autonomous vehicle systems not only enhance safety but also hold the promise of reshaping urban mobility, reducing traffic congestion, and minimizing environmental impact.

Moreover, the project has had a significant impact on education and workforce development. It has facilitated the creation of advanced courses and seminars, enriching the academic experience for students and preparing them for careers in a rapidly evolving technological landscape. Our efforts have supported the growth of future leaders in the field, with several PhD students completing their dissertations based on the research conducted under this project. Particularly, three PhD students who have been (partially) funded by this project joined Wayne State University as tenure-track assistant professor, UC Berkeley as PostDoc research scientist, and University of Maryland at College Park as PostDoc research scientist, respectively. These emerging scholars are now contributing to academia and industry, carrying forward the insights and innovations developed through this project.

As we conclude this project, we reflect on the strides we've made towards creating a more connected, efficient, and safe technological future. The "D3" ecosystem stands as a testament to the power of innovative research in addressing the complex challenges of our time. While our project has reached its completion, the journey of discovery and impact continues. The knowledge and tools we've developed are now being integrated into new systems and applications, promising to enhance the quality of life and security for people around the globe.

In summary, the "D3" project has not only achieved its goals but has also set the stage for future advancements in embedded and real-time systems. Its contributions to the field and society at large underscore the importance of continued investment in research that pushes the boundaries of what's possible, ensuring that technology remains a force for good in our ever-changing world.

 


Last Modified: 02/13/2024
Modified by: Cong Liu
